g:HTMLPanel.div: When constructing an artificial language we sometimes want to speak explicitly about one particular individual. For this reason, we define constants. A constant is a name which refers to exactly one individual. For example, when we write 'a_1' we refer to one and only one individual. But one individual can have more than one name. Below you see the current table of Individuals and their constants.

ul.li: Notes for the semantical/ontological level: To model that an individual has certain properties or an individual has a relation to other individuals, one needs predicates. In each world, one predicate PRED is assigned to one extension. The extension describes which individuals have this property PRED or which individuals are in this particular relation PRED with each other.

Notes for the syntactical level: To refer to a predicate we need unamigious names again. Our language only allows uppercase predicate names like SMALLERTHAN or RED. Additionally to the name of the predicate, one has to append the arity with a leading '^'. To summarize for one example: SMALLERTHAN^2 refers to one and only one predicate.
General Note: If you create a predicate, the system automatically creates an empty extension for each world. You can modify them later in the World-View.
